messageBody:
Dear All,

I am writing a struts-based web application (not really relevent for this
discussion however...). I have a number of implementations of Action (used
to service incoming Http requests). My action classes collaborate with a
number of other classes (data access, business and so forth) and I would
like to unit test my Action classes. However they really only have one
public method of interest - the Action.execute, and this is I believe,
currently, far to complex for sensible unit testing, what I really want is
to test some of the collaborations (parts of the whole).

Obviously I can (and have) refactored Action.execute and this has resulted
in a number of protected and private methods. But unit testing seems be
aimed at public interface testing, which my newly refactored methods do not
come under this description. I am not keen to promote these methods to
public visibility because they are not part of the behavioural interface.
My current thought (but I am not happy with this) is to do the following:
subclass my target testing class and provide a number of public methods that
simply forward to the appropriate underlying protected method(s) and
recording their results (to be tested by Junit asserts). This works but
leaves me with the overhead of having to "maintain" my target subclass along
with the rest of my application. Things are compounded somewhat by the fact
that I am also having to mock a fair number of objects in order to make my
action class as independent as possible.

Has anyone else come across a similar problem and if so how did you solve
it? I am still a relative newbie to unit testing (and very much a newbie)
to testing complex interactions so any help/thoughts greatly appreciated.

TIA

Jonathan
